My wife recently started practicing Tibetan Buddhism and she talks about her "lama" with this reverence that honestly scares me. She bows to his photo, she travels to see him, she calls him her most important teacher. I love her but is this a cult?

Your concern comes from a real place and I'm not going to dismiss it. You're watching someone you love change, and the language around it sounds alarming from the outside.

Here's what I can offer: there are concrete ways to tell the difference between a healthy teacher-student relationship and a cult dynamic. Check these against what you're actually seeing.

Healthy signs: She can freely discuss doubts about the teacher. She's encouraged to examine the teachings critically. The teacher doesn't control her finances, social life, or decisions outside of practice. She's becoming kinder, more grounded, more present — not more anxious or isolated. She maintains relationships outside the community. She can skip a teaching without consequences.

Warning signs: She's told doubts are her own spiritual failing. Questioning the teacher is forbidden. There's financial pressure or escalating demands on her time. She's pulling away from family and non-Buddhist friends. She seems anxious about displeasing the teacher. She's been told you're an obstacle to her practice.

The bowing and the reverence — those look strange from outside, but they're standard practice in Tibetan Buddhism going back centuries. It's not inherently different from kneeling in church. The tradition actually teaches that you should carefully examine a teacher before committing, and that the most important quality is genuine compassion, not authority.

Talk to her. Not with "is this a cult" but with "help me understand what this means to you." Her answer will tell you more than any checklist. If she can explain it openly, if she's willing to hear your concern without panic, that's a good sign.

If you see the warning signs, though — take them seriously. They're real regardless of the spiritual tradition.

I feel genuine devotion for my teacher but I'm embarrassed about it. Like, I'm a professional adult with a career and here I am tearing up during teachings. My friends would think I've lost it. Is something wrong with me?

Nothing is wrong with you. Something is working.

The embarrassment makes perfect sense culturally. Modern Western life doesn't have a framework for what you're experiencing. We have frameworks for romantic love, for admiring a mentor, for fan loyalty — but genuine spiritual devotion doesn't fit any of those boxes. So the mind panics and calls it weird.

But consider: you're a professional adult precisely because you've learned to manage your emotions, perform competence, and keep things controlled. Devotion cracks that open. Tearing up during teachings isn't losing control — it's something in you recognizing truth at a level deeper than professional composure. That recognition is actually valuable and not easy to come by.

The tradition takes this seriously. Devotion isn't considered emotional weakness or regression. It's understood as a response to encountering genuine wisdom — something in you recognizes it even before the intellect can name it. The texts talk about gazing at the spiritual master "without satiation" because meeting an authentic teacher is rare and precious.

Your friends would think you've lost it because they haven't encountered what you've encountered. That's not their fault, and it doesn't make your experience less real. You don't need to explain it to everyone. Not everything that's true needs to be publicly defended.

The tears are doing something the professional composure can't. Let them.

My best friend does full prostrations in front of a photo of her Buddhist teacher every morning. She's smart, has a PhD, and this just doesn't compute for me. Should I be worried?

I understand why this looks alarming. A smart, educated person bowing to a photo seems like it should be a red flag.

But consider what prostrations actually are in this tradition. They're not worship the way you might think of it. They're a physical practice designed to work on something the intellect can't touch — the deep habit of putting yourself at the center of everything. The body bows, and something in the mind's grip on "I know best" loosens slightly. Do it enough times and the habitual arrogance that keeps you trapped in your own perspective starts to soften.

It's not that different from any physical discipline — martial artists bow entering a dojo, not because the room is divine but because the gesture does something to the mind. The photo represents the teacher and the lineage of teachings, not a personality to worship.

The PhD actually makes this make more sense, not less. Someone who's spent years developing the intellect sometimes hits the limit of what thinking alone can do. Prostrations work on a different register entirely.

That said, your instinct to pay attention to your friend isn't wrong. Here's what would actually concern me: if she's isolating from friends, if she can't tolerate questions about her practice, if the community pressures her financially, if she seems more anxious than grounded. Those would be real warning signs regardless of the tradition.

But smart person with a daily physical practice who's otherwise living her life well? That's not a crisis. That's someone who found something that works at a level intellect alone doesn't reach.

After reading about all the abuse scandals in Tibetan Buddhism, I can't bring myself to do guru yoga anymore. The whole practice feels tainted. But my teacher hasn't done anything wrong. Am I being unfair?

You're not being unfair. You're having a sane response to real information.

The scandals are not exaggerations. Real teachers abused real students, and institutional structures enabled it. That happened. And when you learn that the very mechanism of devotion — the trust, the surrender, the seeing-the-teacher-as-buddha — was weaponized to silence victims, it makes sense that the practice now feels contaminated.

Here's what might help untangle it. Guru yoga is about recognizing the enlightened qualities transmitted through the teacher, not about the teacher being flawless. But the tradition's own framework for this is clear: you examine the teacher first, rigorously, using both the Buddha's words and your own experience. Where abuse happened, that examination either didn't happen or was actively suppressed. The failure wasn't in the practice — it was in skipping the examination that's supposed to come before the practice.

Your teacher hasn't done anything wrong. You've presumably examined them and found them trustworthy. The practice of seeing the transmission they carry as precious is a different thing from the blind devotion that enabled abuse elsewhere.

But if you're not ready to return to guru yoga right now, that's also fine. There's no timeline for this. Practice what you can practice authentically. A forced guru yoga done through gritted teeth isn't guru yoga — it's performance.

Maybe for now, attend your teacher through practice and persistence in the other teachings. That's described as the form of attending that matters most anyway. The devotional dimension may return on its own when trust has had time to rebuild.

The fact that you care about doing this honestly is itself a sign of genuine practice.

My therapist says my relationship with my Buddhist teacher sounds like a trauma bond or codependency. She thinks I'm projecting a parental figure. I trust my therapist but I also trust my teacher. I'm torn.

This is a genuinely difficult collision between two frameworks that each see part of the truth.

Your therapist isn't wrong to look for those patterns. Projection onto authority figures is real. People do unconsciously seek parental substitutes, especially if early attachment was disrupted. And some teacher-student relationships in spiritual communities absolutely do become codependent. Your therapist is doing her job by naming what she sees.

But the therapeutic framework has a blind spot here. It doesn't have a category for healthy spiritual devotion. When the only lens available is attachment theory and trauma patterns, everything that looks like deep trust in an authority figure gets coded as pathology. A hammer sees nails.

The question isn't whether your devotion contains some projection — it almost certainly does, because we're human and we bring our patterns everywhere. The question is whether the relationship is functioning to wake you up or to keep you dependent.

Signs it's working: You're developing your own discernment, not just deferring to the teacher's opinions. Your life is functioning better, not worse. You can disagree with the teacher without existential panic. You're becoming more independent over time, not less. The teacher encourages your autonomy.

Signs it's not: You can't make decisions without consulting the teacher. You feel anxious when you haven't had contact. Your world is shrinking to revolve around the community. You suppress your own perceptions to match the teacher's.

You don't have to choose between therapist and teacher. Use the therapy to examine your patterns honestly. Use the teacher for what the therapy can't touch. If both are good at their jobs, they're working on different layers of the same person.

My teenage daughter came home from a meditation retreat and now she's bowing to a picture of some Buddhist guy in her room. I'm trying to be open-minded but I'm also her parent. What am I dealing with here?

Fair concern. You're her parent and you should be paying attention.

First, some context. In Tibetan Buddhism, bowing to a teacher's image is standard practice, similar to how a Christian might kneel before a cross or a martial artist bows entering the dojo. It's not worship in the way it might look. The practice is meant to counteract self-centeredness — the physical act of bowing works on mental habits that intellectual understanding alone doesn't touch.

That said, teenagers are also vulnerable to charismatic communities and intense group experiences. A retreat can create powerful feelings of belonging and meaning, and it's worth understanding what's actually happening.

Questions worth exploring with her, calmly and without accusation: What did they actually teach? Is she welcome to ask questions and express doubts? Does the community encourage her to maintain her other relationships and responsibilities? Did anyone ask her for money or make promises about special status? Does the teacher encourage students to think for themselves?

Good signs: She can explain what she's doing and why. She's still engaged with school, friends, other interests. She seems calmer or more thoughtful, not more anxious. The community is transparent about who they are.

Concerning signs: Secrecy about what happens at the group. Pressure to attend more events. Distancing from non-Buddhist friends. An us-vs-them mentality. Being told her family "doesn't understand."

The best thing you can do is stay curious and stay connected. Ask about it like you'd ask about any new interest — with genuine curiosity, not interrogation. If what she found is real and healthy, your openness will strengthen your relationship. If something is off, keeping communication open is how you'll know.

Can you explain how guru devotion in Tibetan Buddhism is actually different from cult dynamics? Because from the outside, the similarities are uncomfortable.

You're right that the surface similarities are uncomfortable, and pretending they don't exist doesn't help anyone.

Both involve deep trust in a leader, special language, committed community, and practices that outsiders find strange. The differences are structural, not cosmetic.

The examination requirement. The tradition explicitly teaches: examine a teacher carefully before relying on them. Don't trust a first impression. Test them against the Buddha's words and your own experience. This examination period is supposed to take years, not minutes. Cults do the opposite — they rush commitment and discourage investigation.

The direction of dependency. In healthy teacher-student relationships, the student becomes more independent over time, not less. The goal is your own realization, not permanent devotion to the leader. The teacher is compared to a physician — you go to them because you're sick, with the goal of getting well and no longer needing the doctor. Cults create increasing dependency.

Transparency about power. Healthy communities acknowledge that the teacher-student dynamic creates vulnerability and take steps to prevent abuse. Unhealthy ones use the concept of "pure perception" to silence complaints.

Freedom to leave. You can walk away from a Buddhist teacher. Your community shouldn't shun you, your relationships shouldn't collapse, and no one should threaten spiritual consequences for leaving.

The uncomfortable truth is that some Buddhist communities fail these tests. When a community suppresses questioning, demands unconditional obedience, isolates members, or uses devotion to enable abuse — that's cult dynamics wearing Buddhist clothes. The tradition's own standards condemn it.

The framework for healthy devotion exists. Whether any specific community follows it is the question that matters.

I'm new to Buddhism and honestly the teacher devotion stuff makes me deeply uncomfortable. I came for meditation and philosophy, not to venerate someone. Do I have to do this?

No, you don't have to do any of it. And your discomfort is worth listening to rather than overriding.

Many people enter Buddhism through meditation and philosophy, and that's a perfectly valid path. The Theravada tradition, Zen, and secular Buddhism all offer profound practice without the devotional element that Tibetan Buddhism emphasizes. If devotion isn't where you are, there's no obligation to force it.

That said, it's worth understanding what the devotional aspect is actually for, even if you choose not to engage with it.

The intellectual mind is powerful but it has limits. You can understand emptiness conceptually and still be completely trapped by your habits. You can explain interdependence eloquently and still live as if you're the center of the universe. The devotional practices work on the parts of you that philosophy can't reach — the deep-seated sense of being separate, in control, self-sufficient. Bowing isn't degrading yourself. It's loosening the grip of a self-image that keeps you stuck.

But that only works when it's genuine. Forced devotion is just performance, and it won't do anything useful.

If you're early on the path, start where you are. Meditate. Study the teachings. Find a teacher whose instructions make sense to you and whose presence you trust. If devotion arises naturally over time as you deepen in practice, it won't feel forced — it will feel like the next honest step. If it never arises, you can still walk the path.

The worst thing you can do is perform devotion you don't feel. That's not practice. That's theater.

People on the internet keep saying Tibetan Buddhism is basically a cult because of the whole guru thing. I've been practicing for two years and now I feel defensive and confused. How do I process this?

The internet is good at generating heat and bad at generating light on this topic.

Here's what's actually happening in those discussions. There are three groups talking past each other: genuine abuse survivors whose experiences are real and serious, anti-religion skeptics who would say the same about any spiritual tradition, and defenders who dismiss all criticism as spiritual failing. None of them are having the same conversation.

Your defensiveness is normal. When something meaningful to you gets flattened into "it's a cult," the instinct is to defend. But defensiveness isn't clarity. And confusion means you're actually holding the complexity instead of collapsing to a simple position, which is harder but more honest.

Some things are simultaneously true: The teacher-student structure in Tibetan Buddhism has been abused, badly, by specific teachers in specific communities. The teacher-student structure in Tibetan Buddhism has also produced genuine liberation and benefit for countless practitioners over centuries. These aren't contradictory. A system can be both valuable and vulnerable to corruption.

The tradition itself addresses this directly. Gampopa teaches: examine a teacher carefully. Use the Buddha's words and your own experience. If a teacher is overpowered by afflicting emotions, the relationship will bring confusion. This isn't modern damage control — it's 12th-century instruction. The framework for healthy discernment has always been there. Where abuse happened, this framework was ignored.

Don't process internet arguments. Process your own experience. Is your teacher trustworthy by the tradition's own standards? Is your practice making you more clear or more confused? Are you freer than when you started, or more constrained?

Those answers matter. Reddit threads don't.

My partner spends significant money traveling to see their Buddhist teacher several times a year, and donates to the center on top of that. We're not wealthy. Is this normal or should I be worried?

Both your concern and their commitment deserve to be taken seriously here.

In the tradition, offering material support to a teacher and their community is one of the recognized ways to attend a spiritual master. It's considered genuinely meaningful practice, not just fundraising. Traveling to receive teachings in person makes sense when the teacher you've connected with isn't local — some teachings can only be received in person, and the relationship between teacher and student is central to how the tradition works.

That said, financial strain on a shared household is a real problem, and spiritual practice that causes suffering to the people around you has missed its own point. If your partner's generosity is creating genuine hardship for your family, that's not devotion — that's one commitment overriding others.

The question isn't whether the spending is "normal for Buddhism" — it's whether it's sustainable for your actual life together.

Here's what to watch for. In a healthy community: donations are genuinely voluntary, there's no pressure to give beyond your means, the teacher doesn't live lavishly while students struggle, and no one is made to feel that their spiritual progress depends on financial contribution.

In an unhealthy one: there's implicit or explicit pressure to give more, guilt around not donating enough, escalating financial expectations, or a sense that access to the teacher correlates with generosity.

The conversation you need to have with your partner isn't about whether their practice is valid. It's about shared finances and shared decisions. If your partner can explain their spending clearly, if you can agree on boundaries that work for both of you, and if they can hear your concern without treating it as an attack on their practice — that's healthy. If the conversation can't even happen, that's the real warning sign.
